snippet: Mr. Carpenter’s flight into space was in May 1962. Before the first mission to orbit the Earth, in February that same year, he famously told another astronaut, “Godspeed, John Glenn.”
abstract: Astronaut Scott Carpenter, whose flight into space in 1962 as the second American to orbit the Earth was marred by technical problems and ended with the nation waiting anxiously to see if he had survived a landing far from the target site, dies at age 88; he was one of the last two surviving astronauts of America's original space program, Project Mercury.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Carpenter’s flight into space was in May 1962. Before the first mission to orbit the Earth, in February that same year, he famously told another astronaut, “Godspeed, John Glenn.”

headline.main: Scott Carpenter, One of the Original Seven Astronauts, Is Dead at 88
headline.print_headline: Scott Carpenter, 2nd Mercury Astronaut to Orbit the Earth, Dies at 88
